page1:
Page 1 – Executive metrics overview

We closed the period at £9.8m ARR across 161 customers, with an ARR per customer of ~£61k and headcount 60. Growth and unit economics remain strong overall, but momentum is slowing and retention quality is mixed.

  • Growth: ARR growth is 42% (vs 19% benchmark), supported by steady new lands and expansion (see Page 2). However, Page 2 shows quarterly growth decelerating to 25% in the latest period—flagging a near‑term slowdown.
  • Margins and mix: Gross margin 78% and recurring margin 80% are healthy and stable (Page 3 trend confirms 78%). Non‑recurring margin is high at 28%, but with 96% of revenue recurring, overall mix remains SaaS‑weighted.
  • Retention: Logo retention sits at 91% (in line with benchmark), but gross retention 87% (below 91% benchmark) points to elevated downgrades/attrition. Net retention is 101% (at benchmark) but, per Page 2, has softened from earlier highs—an area to tighten.
  • Efficiency: S&M at 27% of revenue, Dev at 28%, and G&A at 19% are all better than benchmarks (32%, 33%, 22% respectively), underpinning EBIT margin 4% and Rule of 40 at 46%. CAC ratio of 0.59 and LTV:CAC 10.1 signal strong payback, consistent with Page 3 efficiency metrics, though Page 3 shows LTV:CAC trending nearer 7.1 most recently—still strong but drifting down.
  • Productivity: ARR per head 163 (vs 77 benchmark) remains a key strength, helped by margin discipline (Page 3) and controlled S&M intensity.

Takeaway: The business is executing efficiently with strong unit economics and positive EBIT. The priority is to arrest the recent deceleration and lift gross retention back toward/above benchmark without sacrificing efficiency.
page2:
Page 2 – Logos, ARR and deal dynamics

We grew the logo base from 95 → 182 over the period, with healthy new logo flow but rising churn pressure and slower net growth.

  • Logo flow: New logos stepped up from 35 to the mid‑50s per period, but lost logos also increased (e.g., -17 in the latest period). Logo retention improved from the low 80s to ~90–92% earlier, but has eased to 88–89% recently.
  • ARR engine: ARR Bf rose from £4.1m → £8.7m. Expansion remained robust (peaking ~£956–919k), but downsells (e.g., -£531k) and attrition (e.g., -£938k) increased in the latest periods. As a result, ARR retained grew to £8.1m but with more friction.
  • Growth quality: Gross retention drifted from ~89–91% to 83% in the latest period, and net retention moderated from 103% to 94%. Growth % decelerated from the 30–40% range to 25% most recently.
  • Land and pipeline: New‑logo ARR (“Land”) increased from ~£1.75m to ~£2.75m per period, and Deals volume/value climbed from £2.47m to ~£4.01m, indicating continued top‑of‑funnel health.
  • Implication for Page 1 metrics: Strong lands and expansion support the current 42% ARR growth, but retention softness explains why gross retention (87%) underperforms benchmark and why net retention (101%) has flattened.

Actions: Focus CS and pricing on cohorts with higher downsell/attrition to lift gross retention back toward 90%+, while sustaining land momentum.
page3:
Page 3 – P&L and headcount

The model is scaling with consistent gross margins and improving operating leverage, translating to sustained profitability.

  • Topline: Total revenue increased from £5.1m → £10.1m; recurring revenue is the driver (£4.9m → £9.8m). Non‑recurring is modest (£243k → £334k), consistent with the 96% recurring mix on Page 1.
  • Gross margin: Value and percentage are steady at ~78% throughout, validating pricing and delivery efficiency.
  • OpEx mix: S&M declined from 31% → ~24–25%; G&A from 19% → 16%; R&D held ~28–29%. This mirrors Page 1 where % of revenue for S&M/Dev/G&A beat benchmarks.
  • Profitability: EBIT improved from -£83k (-2%) to £943k (9%). Rule of 40 on this page runs ~35–46% across periods; the Page 1 headline 46% reflects the latest/TTM view.
  • Efficiency: CAC ratio ~0.60–0.61 and LTV:CAC ~7.1 in the latest period corroborate Page 1’s strong efficiency (headline 0.59 and 10.1), noting a recent downtick that warrants monitoring.
  • Headcount: Total grew from 37 → 64, weighted to Development (17 → 33), with S&M scaling more modestly (11 → 16). Productivity remains high (Page 1 ARR/head 163 vs 77 benchmark).

Outlook: We have room to reinvest some EBIT into growth initiatives targeted at retention and selected segments while keeping EBIT positive, given stable gross margin and disciplined OpEx.
page4:
Page 4 – Cohorts, segments and geography

The segment view highlights where churn/downsells are concentrated and where expansion/land is strongest, explaining the retention softness seen on Pages 1–2.

  • ARR trajectory: On the rolling 12‑month view, ARR rises from ~£3.1m → £4.9m, but gross retention trends down from ~99% → 89% and net retention from ~106% → 88%, consistent with Page 2’s recent 83% gross and 94% net.
  • Verticals: Largest verticals are Energy & Utilities (£1.99m), Government (£1.19m), 3rd Sector & Education (£0.94m), and Finance & Professional Services (£0.75m). Net growth is strongest in Energy (~49%) and solid in Finance (~40%); Life Sciences (~£0.41m) shows slight contraction. Prioritize CS and pricing defenses in Life Sciences; double‑down on proven plays in Energy and Finance.
  • Geography: ARR by region is led by Asia (£1.99m; net growth ~42%) and balanced across Africa (£1.11m; 24%), Europe (£1.08m; 72%), and North America (£1.03m; -46%). North America is the standout headwind with lower gross retention (~61%) despite sizable land activity—this is the main driver of weaker gross retention overall.
  • Cohort heatmap: Expansions (green 113s) are broad‑based across many customers, but we see pockets of downsells (reds/25s) and cancellations clustered in later months. This concentration aligns with the segment/geographic patterns above.

Actions: 1) Run targeted save/expansion plays in North America and Life Sciences (executive coverage, packaging, term/price alignment). 2) Replicate successful motions in Energy & Utilities and Europe to sustain land/expansion. 3) Tighten renewal hygiene to lift gross retention back toward 90%+ within two quarters.
